H0.text: Mimicry is the process by which the hundreds of spots on newborn white‑tailed deer coats, which gradually disappear at three to four months of age, help the newborns blend in with the environment.

H1.text: Migration is the process by which newborn white‑tailed deer, which have hundreds of spots on their coats that gradually disappear at three to four months of age, blend in with the environment.

H2.text: Hibernation is the process that allows newborn white‑tailed deer, which have hundreds of spots on their coats that gradually disappear at three to four months of age, to blend in with the environment.

H3.text: Camouflage is the way newborn white‑tailed deer, which have hundreds of spots on their coats that gradually disappear at three to four months of age, blend in with the environment.

A4.text: Caterpillar resembling bird droppings on leaves.

A6.text: Several species such as the chital, the fallow deer and the sika deer feature white spots on a brown coat.

A7.text: Its mother licks it clean until it is almost free of scent, so predators will not find it.
